content.description:
Climb the right arete of the

MoSo Roof

block.  Start scrunched up on the right side of the same rail that

MoSo Roof

starts on, and hit the 2 finger pocket with your right hand. Go up and left from here topping out on jugs. The large block at the base is off for your feet.
content.location:
This is located on the right arete of the

MoSo Roof

block.

content.description: Start low on crimps in the seam, move out to the arete, then go up.
content.location:
Low on the ridge line, either move down from the main trail before reaching

Dasani

, or head up from the trail that follows the drainage at the parking lot.

content.description:
Hall & Oates starts matched on the long, obvious, start rail in the middle of the boulder facing downhill. Fire up and left to a thin crimp, and head up from there. The topout is a little tricky. It has really cool movement on a beautiful orange boulder! There are two variations: Hall (V8) is going right hand up first to the crimp which leads to matching the crimp rail. The Oates (V8) variation goes up to the crimp with your left hand leading to a hard lockoff straight up to a decent hold.

youtube.com/watch?v=cJ1CedD…
content.protection: A few pads, the crux is low.
content.location:
The Hall & Oates Boulder is located at the same level on the hogback as

Moso Roof

just farther right about 100 yards next to a pine tree. It is hard to see from above.

content.description:
Start in the right-angling jug crack (right of

Hall & Oates

). Fire up to decent pockets on the bulge, work your way on top, and head up and left. The topout is tricky, and attentive spotters are a must! Maneater is last clip in the video below VVV:

youtube.com/watch?v=cJ1CedD…
content.location:
The Hall & Oates Boulder is located at the same level on the hogback as

Moso Roof

just farther right about 100 yards next to a pine tree. It is hard to see from above.

content.description: This is a somewhat neglected but fun problem with a delicate start to a good mantling hold to a kinda scary but relatively easy high finish. Start to the left underneath the arete on good holds. Move right and straight up the shallow dihedral using a couple good but small holds. Establish yourself on the delicate feet, and make a move to the good hold on the arete. Mantle over the good hold to an ok hold on the slab and climb up the easier terrain to the top. I would avoid falling off the top, as it wouldn't be pretty.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter, more than one if possible.
content.location:
This is left of

Blood Moon

.

content.description:
Stand start this, the sit start not yet been established.

Start on left hand sidepull and right hand crimp, then bump up to the large, half moon-shaped rail to the roof. From here, figure out the beta yourself, we tried three different ways before sending; however, there is very different beta for shorter people.
content.protection: Pads... lots of pads. The landing is great with 3-4 pads before pulling the roof. After the roof, it's just straight sketchy.
content.location: From the parking lot, hike up the stairs to the first fork. Take the right hand fork trail, and follow it till it heads up to a large boulder. You can't miss it.

content.description: This arete starts low on a sloper around the arete and a sloping edge on the east side of the problem. Slap up the right side then do whatever to top it out. It has cool slopers, a good angle, and a perfect setting.
content.protection: Employ two pads. It is a highball, but the landing is not that bad. This is better than most of the landings at MoSo. A spotter is recommended.
